wikipedia_page.main: Michael James Whitty (born 1795, Duncormick, County Wexford – died 10 June 1873, Princes Park, Liverpool) was an Irish-born English newspaper editor and proprietor.Whitty was a former Chief Constable for Liverpool, who had campaigned for the abolition of the Stamp Act under which newspapers were taxed.When the abolition took place, Whitty began publishing the Daily Post at one penny per copy, undercutting the incumbent best-selling Liverpudlian newspaper, the Liverpool Mercury.Whitty is buried in Anfield Cemetery. The journalist Edward Michael Whitty was his son.

response: The Liverpool Daily Post was first published in 1855 by Michael James Whitty. Whitty, a former Chief Constable for Liverpool, had campaigned for the abolition of the Stamp Act under which newspapers were taxed. When the abolition took place, Whitty began publishing the Daily Post at one penny per copy, undercutting the incumbent best-selling Liverpudlian newspaper, the Liverpool Mercury.

Whitty was born in Liverpool, England, to William Alfred Whitty ( 1837–1876), a newspaper proprietor,L.H.J., "Histrionic Geography", The Stage (2 March 1893), p. 9. and Mary Louisa (née Ashton, c. 1837–1894). Her grandfather was Michael James Whitty, Chief Constable in Liverpool and founder of the Liverpool Daily Post. She made her first stage appearance in Liverpool in 1881, later moving to London to appear in the West End.

Buried in the cemetery are the artist William G. Herdman (1805–82), the boxer Jem Mace (died 1910), and T. J. Hughes, founder of a chain of shops bearing his name.  Also buried in the cemetery are four recipients of the Victoria Cross: Patrick Mylott (1820–78) and John Kirk (1827–65), both of whom served in the Indian Mutiny, Joseph Prosser (1828–67) who served in the Crimean War, and Donald Dickson Farmer (1877–1956) who served in the Second Boer War. Other notable burials or cremations include the cotton merchant James Maybrick (1838–89), the footballer Joe Fagan (1921–2001), the singer Michael Holliday (1924–63), and the musician Rory Storm (1938–72). In the cemetery are the graves of the newspaper proprietor Michael James Whitty (1793–1873), and William Herbert Wallace (1878–1933), who was convicted, then acquitted, of murdering his wife.

The son of Michael James Whitty, was born in London, and was educated at the Liverpool Institute and in Hanover. About 1844 he became a reporter on the provincial press, and from 1846 to 1849 he was the writer of the parliamentary summary of The Times. He was also the London correspondent of the Liverpool Journal.
* Michael James Whitty (1795–1873), English newspaper editor and proprietor
